full_transcript:
[10.6s - 17.3s]: Welcome to the Why On Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[17.5s - 23.7s]: we're visiting with author, Lathem Matthews. Hi, Lath, how you doing? I'm fine. How are you doing, Aaron?

[23.7s - 31.9s]: Doing great. Thanks. Lathem Matthews is a Buddhist economist and author. After graduating from

[31.9s - 39.1s]: the University of Washington in economics, he attended the 1984 Vajra Doctube Buddhist Seminary.

[39.8s - 45.6s]: Lath is president of Rigden Financial Inc., and recently joined the faculty of College of New

[45.6s - 51.4s]: Caledonia in Prince George, British Columbia as an instructor of business administration.

[52.2s - 58.1s]: Lath asserts that a wealthy outlook is the first step and the fruition of genuine prosperity.

[58.7s - 65.2s]: He is convinced the best way to help this world spiritually and economically is to make friends with

[65.2s - 72.2s]: oneself at the atomic level. And the best way to do that is through the practice of sitting meditation.

[73.0s - 78.7s]: His book, The Four Noble Truths of Wealth, a Buddhist view of economic life,

[79.3s - 85.3s]: provides the foundation of a deeper form of prosperity, which cools the fires of materialism

[85.3s - 94.4s]: from the inside out. Lathem, I'm so happy that we get the opportunity to visit today. And of course,

[94.4s - 102.9s]: we first met at a green faith, eco faith conference in Boulder. I want to say maybe about five

[102.9s - 108.3s]: years ago, plus or minus. And it's just wonderful to connect with you again. And I'm really excited

[108.3s - 113.9s]: for the opportunity to share with our audience many of your ideas. And of course, your book,

[114.0s - 119.2s]: which I'm holding up here, which is a great read. I've actually read it twice now.

[119.2s - 127.6s]: And I think there are some very pithy nuggets of wisdom that folks will take away from your insights,

[128.3s - 132.9s]: some of which I have repeated probably hundreds of times in the last few years, Lathem. So,

[133.1s - 135.3s]: welcome. It's great to chat with you here.

[136.1s - 144.8s]: Great to be here, Aaron. So, to dive in, what's going on here with your

[145.5s - 152.9s]: background that is both business and finance on the one hand and Buddhism and meditation practice

[152.9s - 160.6s]: on the other. This seems to be a unique nexus and a wellspring for some very important insights.

[169.8s - 177.6s]: idealistic perspective when I entered into university and through family connections. And

[177.6s - 190.2s]: otherwise, I simultaneously had an interest in meditation. And the combination was somehow

[241.0s - 247.8s]: Chokam Trungpa, who wrote a book called Cutting Through Spiritual Materialism, which really sort of

[248.1s - 258.0s]: kills it, just basically gave me a perspective on the whole thing that allowed me to explore

[278.4s - 283.2s]: zero sum point of view? Yeah, sort of like a scarcity orientation, right?

Lath is president of Rigden Financial Inc., and recently joined the faculty of College of New
Caledonia in Prince George, British Columbia as an instructor of business administration.
Lath asserts that a wealthy outlook is the first step and the fruition of genuine prosperity.
He is convinced the best way to help this world spiritually and economically is to make friends with
oneself at the atomic level. And the best way to do that is through the practice of sitting meditation.
